"She (Daenerys) has the power to destroy, she can wipe out entire cities, and we
certainly see that in ‘Fire and Blood.’ We see the dragons wiping out 
entire armies, wiping out towns and cities, destroying them, but that 
doesn’t necessarily enable you to rule — it just enables you to destroy." GRRM

Nikolaj makes a joke/hints about returning to the broken tower in his insta caption.
Me: Don’t make assumptions that he’s going...
body:
Nikolaj makes a joke/hints about returning to the broken tower in his insta caption.

Me: Don’t make assumptions that he’s going to find Jon and Sansa in the broken tower you weirdo! Relax! Don’t run away with the idea. There doesn’t necessarily need to be a broken tower parallel scene.

Also me:

Bonus footage of me totally and completely running away with the idea:

tags: this ask annoyed me so much i had to immediately answer it
like this shit is not what we're about to do
summary: Not all the Stark kids have the same level of importance, GRRM have let pretty clear many times how always the story revolves...
question: Not all the Stark kids have the same level of importance, GRRM have let pretty clear many times how always the story revolves around Arya, Bran and Jon (and Tyrion and Daenerys).
answer:
You mean in the 1996 draft that doesn’t reflect the actual story. GRRM was mad when it got leaked, and has stated that not everything in that version of the story reflects the current story. In that version of the story, Sansa was supposed to choose the Lannisters over the Starks and die around the end of Act 1 in the story. Now, in the current story, Sansa is not only instrumental to the end game of the story, but is 4th character with the most screen-time in the show, and the 5th character with the most chapters in the books. She is also one of the six surviving POV characters from the first book, and the show made it evident that she was here to stay till the final act of the story, making her one of the six major characters in the story. George even exactly that when he said that he wasn’t good with writing outlines, and that is often ‘’making shit up’’ in them, and that ‘’characters changed along the way’’ Now, as mentioned multiple times by GRRM, the story is generally about the 6 key characters, who are simply the POVs from the first book who make it to the end of the story.

 ’‘Little did that guy in the picture imagine that he would be spending most of the next two decades in the Seven Kingdoms of Westeros with Tyrion, Daenerys, Arya, Sansa, Jon Snow, Bran, and all the rest.’’ - GRRM, Not A Blog 2016

You’re right, not all of the Stark kids have the same level of importance. Rickon barely shows up in the story, and Robb is a side character in his mother’s chapters, however, Sansa is a Stark POV introduced in the first book with her set of antagonists, struggles, themes relating to her story, side characters, a training arc among other things. Not only that, but in the same manner as Jon, Arya and Bran, her journey follows quite closely the monomythic journey of the hero. Not to forget that GRRM has reinforced again and again the idea that Sansa is just as much a protagonist as her siblings, with

‘’Yeah, the children were always at the heart of this. The Stark children, in particular, were always very central. Bran is the first viewpoint character that we meet, and then we meet Jon and Sansa and Arya and the rest of them. It was always my intention to do that.’’ - Collider 2011

‘’The kids [Sansa, Arya, and Bran] are a huge part of the story, in many ways the central part of the story.’’ - GRRM, Inside HBO’s Game of Thrones: Season 1 &2 

GRRM even mentioned himself that Sansa as a character really surprised him, and it’s evident just by seeing how different Sansa’s arc was in the original draft compared to the one that she had in this version of the story. Everything that he has said in the past decade and a half only reinforce the idea that Sansa has become just as much of a protagonist as Arya, Bran and Jon. It’s completely ridiculous that he had to mention it this much, but people ignore these interviews and choose to dismiss her because they refused to see her as anything but an unimportant side character who was going to betray her family. She isn’t, not anymore and it’s way past time for people to simply accept that because soon it’s going to be a time for wolves, and that means it will be Sansa’s time as well (where she will make a huge contribution to the future of the continent like the main character she is) and that’s that on that.

summary: Why on Earth couldn't GRRM have had Sandor want to help Sansa because she reminded him of his sister and he felt guilty over her...
question: Why on Earth couldn't GRRM have had Sandor want to help Sansa because she reminded him of his sister and he felt guilty over her death? I saw that suggested in a fic once and it worked really well. Is he allergic to platonic, non-creepy relationships or something?
answer: I really don’t get it. If he envisioned the Hound in the Quiet Isle as the Gravedigger, why didn’t he go with something that didn’t involve sexual abuse? What does it say about his story that a paedophile, who traumatised a child by almost sexually assaulting her, can be redeemed? If the Hound becomes the knight he derided Sansa for believing in, then what does it say about GRRM’s idea of what heroes are made up of? Mine excludes paedophiles, in fact heroes protect children from them. That’s what Brienne is, that’s what she does. If GRRM had any sense, he’d let the Hound fade into the background or at the very least kill him off quickly.

title: Sunshine and Lemons
body:
Myrcella moves north.

King’s Landing is too painful for her to remain, and even if she did she is not sure that she would want to help rebuild. Gendry is crowned king, and Myrcella is relieved. She didn’t want to be a Queen anymore.

Friends forged in a war; Nymeria, Obara and Tyene accompany her. They do not linger, only long enough to make sure that their princess is safe. Arianne remains in Dorne where she has been crowned Queen, and Myrcella writes to her often.

Winterfell is cold, colder than she remembered it being when she visited the Starks so young. But Sansa is bright, and warm, and they easily fall into a friendship reminiscent of their youth. Myrcella had always done her best to be kind to Sansa, even when her mother forbade it. Whispered secrets in the corridors and notes passed when no one was looking. She felt like a little girl again, giddy whenever Sansa giggled. She does that a lot more than she used to, Myrcella noticed.

They share traumas. Sansa tells her about her past, her marriages, and her terrible memories. Myrcella is kind, and soft, and she reminds Sansa that perhaps not every Lannister is so evil. She tells her stories of Dorne and the Sand Snakes, and Sansa listens onto every word. She doesn’t believe in stories anymore, she says, but if she lets herself a little then she doesn’t feel so bad.

Myrcella discovers the beauty of lemon cakes. Jaime has pledged himself to Sansa as Queen in the North, and Myrcella is relieved when she discovers the truth. She knew, she knew all along.

At first, Sansa is wary, but eventually they travel together. Myrcella takes her to Dorne, along with Sansa’s Queensgard. Arya and Brienne and Jaime pretend that they don’t notice anything, but it would be impossible not to. Even blind no-name Arya would have noticed. Myrcella is eager to introduce Sansa to her other family; Arianne and the Sand Snakes.

Nym and Sansa strike up an immediate friendship, and Myrcella tastes her first experience with jealousy.

They return to the North, and Myrcella is surprisingly happy when she feels snow fall on her cheek for the first time since they had left. She had always loved Dorne and the sunshine, but she had never noticed her growing adoration for the snow.

And, she realizes, it is not the snow that her adoration has grown for. It is Sansa, and it has been Sansa all along. Her jealousy, her eagerness to remain in the North where a Lannister did not belong, it fell into place as the snow falls onto frozen grounds.

She comes to Sansa’s chambers in the middle of the night, carrying a candle that wavered as she hurried. She knocked softly on the door and she heard Sansa softly call her in. She was in bed, Myrcella could only make out her form underneath the covers in the candlelight. She lingered, but Sansa opened the covers and Myrcella crawled underneath, setting the candle on the bedside table.

They were like girls again, sharing a bed and secrets and then, now, even kisses.

Give me a Kudos on AO3?
body_abstract:
Myrcella moves north.

King’s Landing is too painful for her to remain, and even if she did she is not sure that she would want to help rebuild. Gendry is crowned king, and Myrcella is relieved. She didn’t want to be a Queen anymore.

reblog.comment:
Myrcella moves north.

King’s Landing is too painful for her to remain, and even if she did she is not sure that she would want to help rebuild. Gendry is crowned king, and Myrcella is relieved. She didn’t want to be a Queen anymore.

[[MORE]]

Friends forged in a war; Nymeria, Obara and Tyene accompany her. They do not linger, only long enough to make sure that their princess is safe. Arianne remains in Dorne where she has been crowned Queen, and Myrcella writes to her often.

Winterfell is cold, colder than she remembered it being when she visited the Starks so young. But Sansa is bright, and warm, and they easily fall into a friendship reminiscent of their youth. Myrcella had always done her best to be kind to Sansa, even when her mother forbade it. Whispered secrets in the corridors and notes passed when no one was looking. She felt like a little girl again, giddy whenever Sansa giggled. She does that a lot more than she used to, Myrcella noticed.

They share traumas. Sansa tells her about her past, her marriages, and her terrible memories. Myrcella is kind, and soft, and she reminds Sansa that perhaps not every Lannister is so evil. She tells her stories of Dorne and the Sand Snakes, and Sansa listens onto every word. She doesn’t believe in stories anymore, she says, but if she lets herself a little then she doesn’t feel so bad.

Myrcella discovers the beauty of lemon cakes. Jaime has pledged himself to Sansa as Queen in the North, and Myrcella is relieved when she discovers the truth. She knew, she knew all along.

At first, Sansa is wary, but eventually they travel together. Myrcella takes her to Dorne, along with Sansa’s Queensgard. Arya and Brienne and Jaime pretend that they don’t notice anything, but it would be impossible not to. Even blind no-name Arya would have noticed. Myrcella is eager to introduce Sansa to her other family; Arianne and the Sand Snakes.

Nym and Sansa strike up an immediate friendship, and Myrcella tastes her first experience with jealousy.

They return to the North, and Myrcella is surprisingly happy when she feels snow fall on her cheek for the first time since they had left. She had always loved Dorne and the sunshine, but she had never noticed her growing adoration for the snow.

And, she realizes, it is not the snow that her adoration has grown for. It is Sansa, and it has been Sansa all along. Her jealousy, her eagerness to remain in the North where a Lannister did not belong, it fell into place as the snow falls onto frozen grounds.

She comes to Sansa’s chambers in the middle of the night, carrying a candle that wavered as she hurried. She knocked softly on the door and she heard Sansa softly call her in. She was in bed, Myrcella could only make out her form underneath the covers in the candlelight. She lingered, but Sansa opened the covers and Myrcella crawled underneath, setting the candle on the bedside table.

They were like girls again, sharing a bed and secrets and then, now, even kisses.

Give me a Kudos on AO3?

summary: Seeing the Stark sisters together, as a team, makes me ridiculously happy.

body: GANG GANG

title: Surely, it’s a total coincidence...
body:
Composition and arrangement of figures…

…has no meaning at all, right?

Who ever cared about who is placed in the middle?

It’s not like being placed in the center makes you “important” or something…

It was the perfect opportunity to erfectly arrange the “ice and fire” couple as the center piece and everyone else on their margins (like JD stans imagine it)

What we got instead is FREAKING AMAZING.
